p: In this paper, we present a potential method of indirectly detecting specific anti-stalk serum immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies against conserved epitopes among group 1 and group 2 influenza A viruses by measuring the difference between the HA head and total HA response; this method, based on a re-adaptation of a competitive ELISA, allows for the discrimination and the quantification of antibodies that are directed against the head and stalk subunits. The construction of a stable headless HA would be an important step both for universal vaccine studies and serological assay use. There have been several studies [ 27, 28, 29] that were animated by the quest to find a stable form of an HA stalk without the head domain, but the correct stabilization and folding of the constructs remain to be evaluated in more detail. In this study, we evaluate the performance of the assay by measuring anti-head and anti-stalk responses in a small panel of human serum samples (adults and children) taken before and after vaccination in the 2009/2010 season.
